table-wrap.anchoringText: This section shows average, minimum and maximum values for bubble point pressure, GOR, OFVFpb, live oil viscosity at buble point pressure and API gravity for each reservoir by play, Table 1 to Table 5. Maps of API, bubble point pressure and viscosity are also shown in Fig. 2 to Fig. 6. The API data involves around 85% of the producing wells and PVT data was compiled from 318 laboratory reports.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: BASAL TENA SANDSTONE AVERAGE PROPERTIES

formatted-caption.caption-text: BASAL TENA SANDSTONE AVERAGE PROPERTIES

table-wrap.anchoringText: This classification consists on typical values of different common measured properties at initial reservoir conditions for each crude oil type. This classification, Table 6, (Lake, 2007) is shown in Fig.7 in form of horizontal bars, samples from Oriente basin (dots) are ordered from shallower, Basal Tena, to deeper, Hollin sandstone in the vertical scale and the few samples from San Pablo – Pacoa basin (triangles) have no depth correlation. From this Fig. 7, initial molecular weight C7+and GOR, most samples lie in the range of heavy oils and some samples in the black oil range.
table-wrap.label: Table 6
table-wrap.caption: Petroleum Fluids and their characteristics

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petroleum Fluids and their characteristics

table-wrap.anchoringText: This classification uses the phase behavior to define crude oil (Craft, 1991;Wheaton, 2016). The average composition, Table 7, for each reservoir was used to generate the phase envelopes shown in Fig.10. It must be noted that even though some PVT samples show higher and lower values for bubble point pressure, the objective of this plot is to show the differences in phase behavior for different crude oils compared with Ecuadorian crude oils
table-wrap.label: Table 7
table-wrap.caption: Composition of several Reservoir Fluids

formatted-caption.caption-text: Composition of several Reservoir Fluids

table-wrap.anchoringText: The following bubble point pressure at reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Standing, 1947, Al-Marhourn, 1988, Dokla-Osman, 1992, Velarde et al, 1997. Statistical results are presented in Table 8, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 13, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 18 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig. C-13
table-wrap.label: Table 8
table-wrap.caption: STATISTICAL RESULTS FOR NON-MODIFIED AND MODIFIED CORRELATIONS FOR BUBBLE POINT PRESSURE

formatted-caption.caption-text: STATISTICAL RESULTS FOR NON-MODIFIED AND MODIFIED CORRELATIONS FOR BUBBLE POINT PRESSURE

table-wrap.anchoringText: The following gas oil ratio at bubble point pressure and reservoir temperature correlations were evaluated: Standing, 1947, Petrosky-Farshad, 1993, Al-Marhoun, 1988, and Hemmati-Kharrat, 2007. Statistical results are presented in Table 9, generic form of correlations is presented in Appendix A, Table 14, original and modified coefficients are presented in Appendix B, Table 19 and graphical comparison of measured and calculated values with modified coefficients is presented in Appendix C, Fig. C-14.
